As a lawyer, I applaud the proposal that lawyers should be required to participate in a "Legalaid" program by which they would provide legal care for the needy at reduced rates paid by the Government ("Health Reform? How About Lawyers," Viewpoints, Sept. 26).
All attorneys qualified to appear before the Federal District Court sitting in Chicago and Rockford, Ill., are required to accept appointments by the court, entirely uncompensated.

Why do lawyers accept this involuntary servitude? I think lawyers recognize that while legal restrictions on the practice of law protect the public, they also restrain competition from non-lawyers; the (perhaps not entirely unintended) consequence of a licensed profession is the increased profit of the professionals. Because the state maintains the profession and enforces the restraints on practice, I believe lawyers know in their hearts that the Government can use them in a small way for the public good.

As for the proposal for "Legalaid," it will find few powerful political allies outside the legal community. Providing poor people with a lawyer allows them to sue and win cases against people with money and political influence. GREGORY J. BUECHE Wheaton, Ill., Sept. 27
